subtasks: Verify that the weather is suitable for planting (after the last frost)
Prepare the soil by adding organic matter for drainage and fertility
Plant seeds either hulled or unhulled, ensuring not to remove the seed coverings
If growing indoors, start plants in peat pots a month before the last frost, sowing seeds one inch deep
Transplant seedlings to the garden when soil temperature is 60-70°F, spacing them 10 inches apart
In northern gardens, thin plants to 10 inches apart after establishing

tasks.task: Hilling the earth around peanut plants
subtasks: When the plant is about a foot tall, mound soil around the base to support the developing peanuts
Apply a light mulch like straw or grass clippings around the plants to maintain soil moisture and allow pegs to penetrate easily
Provide 1 inch of water per week, avoiding excess which can lead to foliage growth over fruiting
Check for readiness when leaves turn yellow and shell markings gold; test by pulling a few nuts from the soil
Pull or dig plants when soil is moist, being careful with the roots
Shake off excess soil, then allow plants to dry in a ventilated area
Once leaves are crumbly, remove unshelled peanuts and store in airtight containers
Choose a full sun location (SUBTASK)

Prepare the soil by amending heavy soil with organic matter for good drainage and fertility (SUBTASK). Wait, the actual conversation was about loosening the soil and adding organic matter, right? So maybe this is part 1.
Plant seeds either hulled or unhulled, but if hulled, ensure the pinkish-brown coverings are retained (SUBTASK).

If growing indoors, plant seeds in peat pots a month before the last frost, sowing one inch deep (SUBTASK). Then after starting, if needed, transplant them when soil is 60-70°F, spacing at 10 inches apart (SUBTASK). Wait, the transcript says "if you have heavy soil" earlier.
